elements.content: Three novel porous coordination polymers based on lead(II) and isonicotinic acid N-oxide, [Pb(INO)2]2·7H2O (1), [Pb(INO)2]·nH2O (2), and [Pb4(OH)4(INO)4]·nH2O (3) (HINO = isonicotinic acid N-oxide), have been synthesized and characterized through single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 features a most remarkable and unique three-dimensional (3D) framework with two distinct kinds of channels showing different sizes and shapes, which are occupied by two kinds of water clusters, according to the size and shape of the channels. Compound 2 possesses a 3D framework built up from one-dimensional (1D) Pb−O chains and INO ligands with 1D rectangular channels, in which lattice water molecules are located. The structure of 3 consists of [Pb4(OH)4]4+ cluster inorganic building blocks, which connect with μ4-INO ligands through oxygen atoms from N-oxide moieties and carboxylate groups of INO to form 8.7 × 8.7 Å2 rhombic channels running along the c-axis. In addition, the photoluminescence properties of coordination polymers 1−3 in the solid state have been reported. Gas adsorption properties of compound 3 have also been studied.
elements.clean_text: Three novel porous coordination polymers based on lead(II) and isonicotinic acid N-oxide, [Pb(INO)2]2⋅7H2O (1), [Pb(INO)2]⋅nH2O (2), and [Pb4(OH)4(INO)4]⋅nH2O (3) (HINO = isonicotinic acid N-oxide), have been synthesized and characterized through single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 features a most remarkable and unique three-dimensional (3D) framework with two distinct kinds of channels showing different sizes and shapes, which are occupied by two kinds of water clusters, according to the size and shape of the channels. Compound 2 possesses a 3D framework built up from one-dimensional (1D) Pb-O chains and INO ligands with 1D rectangular channels, in which lattice water molecules are located. The structure of 3 consists of [Pb4(OH)4]4+ cluster inorganic building blocks, which connect with μ4-INO ligands through oxygen atoms from N-oxide moieties and carboxylate groups of INO to form 8.7 × 8.7 Å2 rhombic channels running along the c-axis. In addition, the photoluminescence properties of coordination polymers 1-3 in the solid state have been reported. Gas adsorption properties of compound 3 have also been studied.

elements.content: Three novel porous coordination polymers based on isonicotinic acid N-oxide and lead(II) were produced by adjusting the pH of the system and the synthetic route. We also investigated the influence of the reaction conditions, such as the pH of the solution and the molar ratio of metal/ligand, on the coordination modes of ligands and coordination numbers and coordination geometries of the metal atoms and consequently the final structure. Significant phosphorescent emission is observed in the three compounds, which may have potential applications in organic light emitting devices.

elements.content: There is currently considerable interest in the synthesis and characterization of porous metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) because of their potential applications in molecular adsorption and separation processes, gas storage, ion exchange, catalysis, sensor technology, and electronics. Generally, the diversity of potential applications in the framework structures of such materials greatly depends on the selection of the metal centers and organic spacers. Recently, some interesting results have been reported in which some transition-metal clusters were linked via polycarboxylate organic anions to form coordination polymers exhibiting unprecedented large cavities and low densities. However, crystal engineering of MOFs is confronted with challenges including the control of the architecture of new molecular building blocks and functionalization of the pores to be expressed in a specific target material. In particular, although these matertials are novel porous materials with appealing properties, compared with conventional inorganic zeolites, the instability of the framework of MOFs such as the collapse of frameworks upon guest removal has been a serious shortcoming of these materials. So the rational design and syntheses of MOFs have been an impetus for property oriented crystal engineering and supramolecular chemistry.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

There is currently considerable interest in the synthesis and characterization of porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) because of their potential applications in molecular adsorption and separation processes, gas storage, ion exchange, catalysis, sensor technology, and electronics. Generally, the diversity of potential applications in the framework structures of such materials greatly depends on the selection of the metal centers and organic spacers. Recently, some interesting results have been reported in which some transition-metal clusters were linked via polycarboxylate organic anions to form coordination polymers exhibiting unprecedented large cavities and low densities. However, crystal engineering of MOFs is confronted with challenges including the control of the architecture of new molecular building blocks and functionalization of the pores to be expressed in a specific target material. In particular, although these matertials are novel porous materials with appealing properties, compared with conventional inorganic zeolites, the instability of the framework of MOFs such as the collapse of frameworks upon guest removal has been a serious shortcoming of these materials. So the rational design and syntheses of MOFs have been an impetus for property oriented crystal engineering and supramolecular chemistry.

elements.content: For several years, Yaghi, Williams, Férey, Kitagawa, Chen, and co-workers have worked in the field of coordination polymers and have considered diverse problems restricting the development of porous MOFs and then developed a strategy to design porous materials. However, most of the work has so far focused on the assembly of d-block metal−organic open frameworks; the analogous chemistry of the main group element remains less developed. In contrast to transition metals, the main group element lead also has a tendency to form polynuclear metal complexes and can provide a stable framework structure. In particular, the PbII ion possesses evidence of coordination sphere distortions as a consequence of the presence of such lone-pairs; so many well-defined cluster-type motifs have been reported, such as Pb2(OH), Pb4(OH)4, Pb6(OH)4O4, Pb6O(OH)6, Pb8O8, Pb6O2 clusters. In addition, the intrinsic features of lead(II), the presence of a 6s2 outer electron configuration, inspire chemists' extensive interest in coordination chemistry, photophysics, and photochemistry. On the other hand, the isonicotinic acid N-oxide (HINO) ligand possesses a longer bridging spacer and richer coordination modes to form a fascinating structure15 compared with isonicotinic acid, as shown in Scheme . Thus, this new type of ligand is expected to more likely form novel hybrid materials with porous three-dimensional (3D) network architectures by the self-assembly with lead ion. Herein, we describe the syntheses and characterization of three novel porous coordination polymers [Pb(INO)2]2·7H2O (1), [Pb(INO)2]·nH2O (2), [Pb4(OH)4(INO)4]·nH2O (3). To the best of our knowledge, no systematic investigation of lead-based porous materials with photoluminescence properties has been documented.

elements.content: Physical Measurements. HINO was prepared from isonicotinic acid. All other chemicals were purchased commercially and were used without further purification. FT−IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000−400 cm-1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. Elemental analyses were carried out with a Carlo Erba 1106 elemental analyzer. The emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were performed from room temperature to 700 °C using a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer under nitrogen at a heating rate of 10 °C /min. Nitrogen adsorption isotherms were measured using the automatic volumetric adsorption equipment (ASAP2020, Shimadzu).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Physical Measurements. HINO was prepared from isonicotinic acid. All other chemicals were purchased commercially and were used without further purification. FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. Elemental analyses were carried out with a Carlo Erba 1106 elemental analyzer. The emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were performed from room temperature to 700 °C using a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer under nitrogen at a heating rate of 10 °C /min. Nitrogen adsorption isotherms were measured using the automatic volumetric adsorption equipment (ASAP2020, Shimadzu).

elements.content: Synthesis of Isonicotinic Acid N-Oxide (HINO). The ligand HINO was synthesized according to the method previously reported in the literature, and their characterizations are detailed in Supporting Information.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Pb(INO) 2 ] 2 ·7H 2 O (1). A mixture of Pb(NO3)2 (0.099 g, 0.3 mmol), isonicotinic acid N-oxide (0.0840 mg, 0.6 mmol), NaOH (0.024 g, 0.6 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was heated in a 23-mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner at 150 °C for 72 h and then was cooled to room temperature at 10 °C/h. Yellow needle crystals were obtained (0.133 g). The pH value of the solution was ca. 3.5. Yield:  81%. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C24H16N4O12Pb2·7H2O:  C, 26.35; H, 2.74; N, 5.12. Found:  C, 26.41; H, 2.85; N, 4.96. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3423s, 3109ms, 1585s, 1544m, 1482w,1378s, 1211s, 1174m, 1137m, 862m, 783w, 682w, 638m.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Pb(INO) 2 ]· n H 2 O (2). The reaction was carried out in a molar ratio of 1:1.5 of Pb(NO3)2 (0.099 g, 0.3 mmol) to isonicotinic acid N-oxide (0.063 mg, 0.45 mmol) in 10 mL of water. To the solution were added NaOH (0.024 g, 0.6 mmol) and 5 mL of DMF, and white precipitate was observed. After the mixture was heated at 80 °C for 30 min with stirring, a majority of precipitate was resolved and then filtered. Yellow crystals were obtained from the filtrate by slow evaporation after standing 2 months at room temperature (yield:  0.033 g, 21% based on Pb). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C12H8N2O7.9Pb:  C, 28.03; H, 1.56; N, 5.45. Found:  C, 27.89; H, 1.67; N, 5.31. IR data (KBr, cm-1):  3418s, 3110ms, 1584s, 1542m, 1479w, 1379s, 1213s, 1176m, 1138m, 863m, 783w, 682w, 638m.

elements.content: X-ray Data Collection and Structure Refinement. Diffraction intensities for 1−3 were collected on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å). The structures were solved with the direct methods using SHELXS-9717 and refined with full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program18 within WINGX. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbons were generated geometrically; the aqua hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps and refined with isotropic displacement parameters. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. In compound 1, hydrogen atoms H3wa, H3wb, H3wc, and H3wd locating on the lattice water molecule O3w are positionallly disordered because of strong hydrogen bonding to O4w and were treated as half occupancy atoms during refinement. The crystal data and structure refinement of compounds 1−3 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1−3 are listed in Table .

Synthesis. Three complexes were designed and synthesized by using the HINO ligand and lead nitrate depending on different pH values and synthesis routes. Compound 1 was obtained under mild hydrothermal conditions in a 1:2 (Pb/HINO) molar ratio, and the pH of the mixture was 3.5. When the same molar ratio of Pb/HINO (1:2) was kept and the final pH values were increased to ca. 5.5, single crystals of 3 were formed. When the final pH value was over 6.5, no crystals were obtained. However, a white powder formed. Other reaction conditions were also attempted, including a different molar ratio, reaction temperature, or other organic solvents instead of water, but no products of 1 and 3, even other products, were afforded. However, compound 2 was prepared at room temperature through the evaporation of solvents; regardless of the Pb/ HINO ratio and the pH value, no compound 2 was obtained under hydrothermal conditions. It is interesting to note that compounds 1 and 2 are two supramoleular isomers unless the lattice water molecules are considered. The characterization data of the complexes are given in the experimental section.

Results and Discussion

 Synthesis. Three complexes were designed and synthesized by using the HINO ligand and lead nitrate depending on different pH values and synthesis routes. Compound 1 was obtained under mild hydrothermal conditions in a 1:2 (Pb/HINO) molar ratio, and the pH of the mixture was 3.5. When the same molar ratio of Pb/HINO (1:2) was kept and the final pH values were increased to ca. 5.5, single crystals of 3 were formed. When the final pH value was over 6.5, no crystals were obtained. However, a white powder formed. Other reaction conditions were also attempted, including a different molar ratio, reaction temperature, or other organic solvents instead of water, but no products of 1 and 3, even other products, were afforded. However, compound 2 was prepared at room temperature through the evaporation of solvents; regardless of the Pb/ HINO ratio and the pH value, no compound 2 was obtained under hydrothermal conditions. It is interesting to note that compounds 1 and 2 are two supramoleular isomers unless the lattice water molecules are considered. The characterization data of the complexes are given in the experimental section.

Description of Crystal Structures. [Pb(INO) 2 ] 2 ·7H 2 O (1). The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system space group Pccn. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one PbII atom, two unique INO ligands in two different coordination modes, and three and one-half independent lattice water molecules. Each PbII center is pentacoordinated and exhibits a distorted square−pyramidal environment supplied by two μ2-O atoms from N-oxide and one carboxylate oxygen (OCOO - ) atom from one INO ligand, one oxygen (ON−O) atom of N-oxide from the other INO ligand, which shows a quasi-plane, and one carboxylate oxygen atom from the second INO ligand in the apical position (see Figure ). The five oxygen atoms are located on one side of the PbII ion, which adopts hemidirected structural categories, suggesting the presence of a stereochemically active lone electron pair around the PbII ion. In fact, each Pb atom in this structure with five normal bonds forms three “weak” Pb···O bonds (Pb1···O2 = 2.856(6), Pb1···O3 = 2.836(6) Å, Pb1···O6 = 2.779(6) Å). Two Pb atoms are linked by two μ-O atoms of INO groups, forming two planar four-membered rings Pb1−O2−Pb1A−O2A and Pb1−O1−Pb1A−O1A. The two four-membered rings link each other to form a one-dimensional (1D) Pb−O chain through a corner-sharing Pb polyhedron along the c-axis (Figure ), where the angle between the two neighboring planes is 82.10°. The Pb2O2 units are bridged by two parallel INO ligands along the a-axis direction and by two other parallel INO ligands along the b-axis direction yielding a 3D framework. In 1, INO ligands adopt two different coordination modes:  one acts as a diconnector to link two PbII centers through an ON−O atom and OCOO - atom along the a-axis (Scheme a), and the other corresponds to a triconnector that links three PbII centers through one μ-O atom and one OCOO - atom in the bc-plane (Scheme d). It is notable that the 3D framework that is different from usual porous material22 contains two alternate 1D channels (A and B) with different sizes and shapes, which is parallel to the c-axis (see Figure S1, Supporting Information). Such biporous materials23 with two (or more) distinct channels make, for example, the simultaneous isolation or transportation of two different guests possible. Channel A is approximately a square, whereas channel B is roughly a rectangle. The approximate dimensions of the channels are 7.0 × 6.9 Å (channel A) and 7.3 × 5.8 Å (channel B) based on d H ··· H through the overall crystal. The guest water molecules, which do not show any covalent interactions, fill in two kinds of channels in different manners, an array of 1D water tube with a double-stranded chain and an ordered 1D hydrogen-bond water chain (Figures and ). The geometrical parameters of water clusters are summarized in Table .

The Pb2O2 units are bridged by two parallel INO ligands along the a-axis direction and by two  other parallel INO ligands along the b-axis direction yielding a 3D framework. In 1, INO ligands adopt two different coordination modes: one acts as a diconnector to link two PbII centers through an ON-O atom and OCOO  -  atom along the a-axis (Scheme a), and the other corresponds to a triconnector that links three PbII centers through one μ-O atom and one OCOO  -  atom in the bc-plane (Scheme d). It is notable that the 3D framework that is different from usual porous material22 contains two alternate 1D channels (A and B) with different sizes and shapes, which is parallel to the c-axis (see Figure S1, Supporting Information). Such biporous materials23 with two (or more) distinct channels make, for example, the simultaneous isolation or transportation of two different guests possible. Channel A is approximately a square, whereas channel B is roughly a rectangle. The approximate dimensions of the channels are 7.0 × 6.9 Å (channel A) and 7.3 × 5.8 Å (channel B) based on d H ⋅⋅⋅ H through the overall crystal. The guest water molecules, which do not show any covalent interactions, fill in two kinds of channels in different manners, an array of 1D water tube with a double-stranded chain and an ordered 1D hydrogen-bond water chain (Figures  and ). The geometrical parameters of water clusters are summarized in Table .

In compound 1, the coexistence of two kinds of water clusters in two distinct channels of one host framework is observed, which displays novel structural aspects of water and provides new insights into water with implications in biological environments. In channel A, as shown in Figure a, O1w is involved in a fully “saturated” hydrogen-bond pattern in these networks, acting as a double donor and a double acceptor to three O2w atoms and one carboxylate oxygen atom (O3) from the ligand with a O1w···O3 distance of 2.780(4) Å. The O2w atom, different from O1w, forms three hydrogen bonds with three neighboring O1w (2.784(3), 2.812(4), 2.833(3) Å) acting as one hydrogen-bond acceptor and a double hydrogen-bond donor. The two independent water molecules (O2w and O1w) are arrayed alternately by hydrogen bonds to produce a 1D water chain. Two water chains entangle together through hydrogen bonds to form a double-stranded helical chain I. Crystallographically, it seems that the helical symmetric operation should exist in the helical chain; however, sometimes it is hard to find it in a complicated structure, though indeed it is there. It should be noteworthy that the right-handed double-helical chain (I‘) is formed by hydrogen-bond bridges between O1w and O2w in the diagonal channel, showing an helical orientation opposite to the former helix. These helices in channel A of the whole structure are alternately arranged in a right- and left-handed sequence, so that the whole structure does not show chirality. Channel B contains a 1D ordered water chain by hydrogen-bonding association. The chain consists of a cyclic (H2O)4 unit involving two independent water molecules (O3w and O4w), belonging to the T4(1) motif24f,25e and further extends along the c-axis (Figure b). Similar structures have been reported recently. O4w atom is located on the axis of the water chain with hydrogen bonds to four neighboring O3w water molecules (O4w···O3w = 2.633(2) Å, 2.616(10) Å) in a tetrahedral arrangement (∠O3w···O4w···O3w = 91.30(3)°, 92.08(12)°) to form a cyclic water tetramer. In contrast to O4w, the O3w is hydrogen bonded to two neighboring O4w water molecules and a carboxyl oxygen O5 (O3w···O5 = 2.924(7) Å). The four oxygen atoms involved in the cyclic tetramer lie in a plane and further assemble into a 1D ordered infinite water chain (II and II‘) by sharing corners of the neighboring tetrameral plane (Figure b), where the angle between the two neighboring planes is 57.57°. It is interesting that two water chains II and II‘ are arranged in an alternate sequence along the opposite direction in channel B of the whole structure.

elements.content: In complex 1, notably, (1) two distinct 1D channels were observed in a 3D coordination network; (2) the lattice water molecules fill in two distinct channels in different manners, and (3) leading to an array of 1D water tube with a double-stranded chain and an ordered 1D water chain involving a cyclic (H2O)4 unit. To the best of our knowledge, such a structure among the metal−organic frameworks synthesized has been rarely reported until now.

elements.content: [Pb 0.5 (INO)]· n H 2 O (2). The single-crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that the structure of compound 2 is a unique 3D open framework in which the asymmetric unit contains half a lead atom, one INO ligand, and several disordered lattice water molecules. As shown in Figure , each PbII center is hexacoordinated in a hemidirected pentagonal bipyramidal geometry supplied by two oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups of two equivalent INO ligands, four oxygen atoms from N-oxide moieties of four INO ligands. Longer distances are observed between Pb and two oxygen atoms (O2 and O2a) from N-oxide moieties (2.863(3) Å), but they are much shorter than Pb−Ocarboxylate bonds (3.11 Å). The distances between Pb and O atoms (ranging from 2.381(3) to 2.863(3) Å) fall in the range for Pb−O covalent bonds (ranging from 2.46 to 2.96 Å). All INO ligands act as triconnectors to link three lead centers through a monodentate carboxylate oxygen atom and μ-O atoms of N-oxide moieties (Scheme d). Two Pb centers are bridged together by two μ-O atoms from two different INO ligands to generate a planar [Pb2O2] ring, imposing Pb···Pb separations of 4.427 Å and O···O separations of 3.049 Å; meanwhile, the adjacent [Pb2O2] units are further assembled into a 1D Pb···O···Pb···O chain (Figure a) by a corner-sharing lead polyhedron, where the angle between the two neighboring planes is ca. 26.4°. Along the INO ligands to different directions that bridge different PbII through μ-O of N-oxide moieties, the structure of compound 2 is expanded into a three-dimensional network with pores of 6.2 × 4.6 Å2 (see Figure b), which are occupied by lattice water molecules.

elements.content: It is interesting that compounds 1 and 2 possess identical chemical composition except lattice water molecules, but their frameworks are apparently different. In 1, INO adopts two kinds of coordination modes as diconnectors and triconnectors to link PbII metal centers, and the PbII center is pentacoordinated and exhibits a distorted square−pyramidal environment. The presence of μ-O contributes to the formation of planar [Pb2O2] rings and 1D infinite Pb−O chains and then results in the formation of a 3D porous framework with two distinct channels. In 2, all INO ligands act as triconnectors to link three PbII centers (Scheme d), but the PbII center is hexacoordinated. Similar to that of 1, there are also [Pb2O2] binuclear units due to the preference of the bridging coordination mode of μ-O atoms in 2. However, the slight difference of coordinate geometry of metal centers results in the change of the angle of adjacent [Pb2O2] four-membered rings from 82.1° for 1 to 26.4° for 2, which makes it adaptable to a different polymeric framework structure with a rectangular channel.

elements.content: [Pb 4 (OH) 4 (INO) 4 ]· n H 2 O (3). The X-ray structure analysis shows that compound 3 crystallizes in the space group P42/nmc with a half of one lead atom, one-half of hydroxyl oxygen, one-half of INO ligand, and several disordered water molecules in an asymmetric unit. Each hepta-coordinated PbII center is bound to three hydroxyl oxygen atoms through μ3-OH atoms, and each μ3-OH bridges to three PbII; thus, it forms a usual M4O4 core that has S 4 site symmetry with metal ions occupying the alternating corners of the distorted cubane core. This core geometry and coordination modes of the structure are similar to Sn4(OH)4 clusters observed in the literature. The Pb4O4 core is bonded to four carboxylate (OCOO - ) groups from four different INO ligands to expand to four different orientations. Each of the other parts of the INO ligand, N-oxide oxygen atoms (ON−O), connects to another Pb4O4 core, resulting in a formal (4,4) net. At the same time, each Pb4O4 cluster unit is bridged by four oxygen atoms (O1) from N-oxides of INO, resulting in the formation of a 1D inorganic metal−oxygen chain running along the c-axis into high-density 3-D networks (Figure b). In compound 3, the Pb−OCOO - (O3) distances are 2.655 Å, the three Pb−O (aqua O2) distances are only 2.376 Å, and the two Pb−ON−O (O1) distances 2.874 Å are longer than those of the remaining Pb−O bonds. The Pb−O bond lengths are in the range from 2.376(1) to 2.874(1) Å (average value 2.616 Å) corresponding to the ones of Pb[1,2-C6H4(NSO2C6H5)2]. The rather high value of the Pb1−O1 bond distance indicates a weak interaction of this oxygen with the metal and shows the presence of a stereochemically active lone pair in that area. Different from those of 1 and 2, the INO ligand acts as a tetradentate ligand and bridges four lead ions through two carboxylate O atoms and one N-oxide oxygen atom (Scheme e) in 3. The resulting 3D networks contain 1D square channels (8.7 × 8.7 Å2; V void 13.9% of the total crystal volume) along the crystallographic c-axis, which were occupied by lattice water molecules through strong hydrogen bonds with the carboxylate oxygen atoms of the INO ligand (see Figure ). This compound also represents, to the best of our knowledge, the first example of a coordination polymer with channels based on lead−oxygen clusters.

elements.content: Compounds 1−3 are all constructed by Pb(II) and the INO ligand but have a remarkable structural and compositional diversity that is achieved due to the differences of the coordination modes of ligands and the coordinate geometry of the metal center. Compound 3 shows a structure totally different from compounds 1 and 2. The notable feature of 3 is that the [Pb4(OH)4]4+ cluster as a building unit was introduced into this system. The pH value of the system seems to facilitate hydroxyl groups of the solution in μ3-O mode to bond with the PbII center, consequently resulting in the formation of a [Pb4(OH)4]4+ cluster. The resulting clusters acting as four-connecting nodes can now be interconnected by four INO ligands into a 3D coordination polymer with larger square channels.

The resulting clusters acting as four-connecting nodes can now be interconnected by four INO ligands into a 3D coordination polymer with larger square channels.

elements.content: Apparently, the formation of MOFs depends on various factors, such as the pH, temperature, solvent, and so on. Our investigation of the Pb(NO3)2/HINO/NaOH/H2O system shows that it is a very pH-sensitive system. Grimes et al. reported that three distinct lead-hydroxo species, [Pb4(OH)4]4+, [Pb3(OH)4]2+, and [Pb6O(OH)6]4+, which formed with pH values from 5.25 to 8.5. In particular, metal−oxygen clusters or secondary building units (SBUs) instead of single metal ions as nodes have been widely employed by Yaghi, Férey, and co-workers9,11 in the construction of stable MOFs with large pores. However, the structures of MOFs based on the assembly of lead−oxygen cluster building units remain largely unexplored. On the basis of this idea and formerly as investigation for the Pb(NO3)2/HINO/NaOH/H2O system, we intended to introduce a metal−oxygen cluster into this system to construct some porous materials by changing the pH of the solution. First, the reaction of Pb(NO3)2 and HINO under mild hydrothermal conditions produces 1 at a pH value of 3.5, which contains [Pb2O2] units generating a 3D framework with two distinct channels. According to the work of Grimes et al., we attempted change the pH value of the system, and finally we successfully synthesized compound 3 containing a [Pb4(OH)4]4+ cubic cluster through a hydrothermal method at a pH of 5.5. Compound 3 exhibits a 3D framework with bigger square channels. On the basis of the above results, we attempted to introduce another metal−oxygen cluster as a building unit into this system and to gain another 3D coordination polymer with a large channel. With this in mind, we have tried our best to change the pH value and the molar ratio of metal/ligand of the solutions under hydrothermal conditions; however, we failed to obtain single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction starting from the same reaction material. So, we tried to change the synthetic route using a traditional method instead of a hydrothermal synthesis method to prepare the expected compound. Fortunately, we obtained another 3D coordination polymer with rectangular channels, compound 2. In this compound, only [Pb2O2] units analogous to that of 1 were observed, and no large metal−oxygen clusters exist in the structure. The results suggest that the pH value can effectively influence the formation of crystal seeds of the family.

elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal stability of the porous MOF of 1−3 under flowing N2. The TGA curve of 1 shows an onset of water loss at a lower temperature of 45 °C and the 3D-MOF begins to decompose above 325 °C (Figure S2, Supporting Information). The first weight loss of 11.15% in the temperature range of 45−310 °C is in accordance with the loss of the lattice water molecules (calculated:  11.54%), while the second weight loss corresponds to the removal of all the organic components to yield PbO (found:  40.5%; calculated:  40.8%). The TGA curve of 2 shows one main weight loss of 5.42% between 35 and 80 °C before the compounds decompose at ca. 310 °C, which corresponds to the loss of the free water molecules (ca. 5.91%) from the channels (Figure S3, Supporting Information). The TGA curve of 3 shows that the first weight loss of 9.88% between 40 and 100 °C corresponds to the loss of the lattice water molecules (ca. 9.82%) in the channels. The anhydrous porous MOF remained stable up to ∼280 °C without any weight loss, showing that the 3D framework could retain structural integrity to ca. 280 °C (Figure S4, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal stability of the porous MOF of 1-3 under flowing N2. The TGA curve of 1 shows an onset of water loss at a lower temperature of 45 °C and the 3D-MOF begins to decompose above 325 °C (Figure S2, Supporting Information). The first weight loss of 11.15% in the temperature range of 45-310 °C is in accordance with the loss of the lattice water molecules (calculated: 11.54%), while the second weight loss corresponds to the removal of all the organic components to yield PbO (found: 40.5%; calculated: 40.8%). The TGA curve of 2 shows one main weight loss of 5.42% between 35 and 80 °C before the compounds decompose at ca. 310 °C, which corresponds to the loss of the free water molecules (ca. 5.91%) from the channels (Figure S3, Supporting Information). The TGA curve of 3 shows that the first weight loss of 9.88% between 40 and 100 °C corresponds to the loss of the lattice water molecules (ca. 9.82%) in the channels. The anhydrous porous MOF remained stable up to ~280 °C without any weight loss, showing that the 3D framework could retain structural integrity to ca. 280 °C (Figure S4, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Moreover, the adsorption properties of compound 3 was investigated at room tempetature. The BET surface area of 3 is calculated to be only 2.51 m2/g, evidently being less than a typical value for microporous MOFs, so compound 3 shows a low adsorption ability to N2 (Figure S5, Supporting Information). These results reveal that only surface adsorption may occur in this case; that is, the nitrogen molecule could not diffuse into the inner channels of these solids freely despite the fact that they possess stable frameworks and large cavities.

elements.content: Luminescent Properties. In this paper, the phosphorescent emission properties of compounds 1−3 were investigated in the solid state. Generally, the appearance of r.t. phosphorescence requires the presence of a heavy metal, which reduces the radiative lifetime of triplets by increased spin−orbit coupling. As shown in Figure , compound 1 exhibits red photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 628 nm upon excitation at 430 nm and the strongest absorption peak at 448 nm upon emission at 660 nm. Compound 3 exhibits an emission maximum at 632 nm upon excitation at 420 nm. In comparison to complex 1, a slight red shift of 4 nm has been observed in compound 3 because of the change of coordination geometry of the metal centers. The luminescent spectrum of compound 2 shows a great change with a blue shift of about 80 nm (λem = 547 nm) compared with those of compounds 1 and 3, which might derive from the slight difference of their structures. The luminescence of compounds 1−3 may be assigned to intraligand phosphorescent emission, while the presence of a heavy metal lead(II) ion facilitates intersystem crossing to successfully compete with radiationless deactivations of the triplet state.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully prepared three novel porous coordination polymers based on isonicotinic acid N-oxide and lead metal by adjusting the pH value of the system and the synthesis route. The complexes all exhibit a regular grid structure, where the stacking of the grids in the structure determines the existence and size of any channels. Compound 1 contains two distinct 1D channels (rectangle and square), in which two kinds of water clusters arrays were observed. The structure of 2 exhibits a 3D network built by a 2D layer and a 1D Pb−O chain with hexagon channels, whereas 3 features a 3D open framework built by [Pb4(OH)4]4+ cluster units with 1D regular square channels. Thus, changing the reaction conditions causes the coordination modes of the ligand and the coordination geometry of metal ions, and consequently, several diversely structural frameworks with different channels to form. Lead ions are inclined to form distinct lead−hydroxo species in a large pH scale, which could act as a node. If other longer bridge ligands are in progress for these systems, much larger porous frameworks are expected. Significant phosphorescent emission is observed in three cases, as is expected from their structures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully prepared three novel porous coordination polymers based on isonicotinic acid N-oxide and lead metal by adjusting the pH value of the system and the synthesis route. The complexes all exhibit a regular grid structure, where the stacking of the grids in the structure determines the existence and size of any channels. Compound 1 contains two distinct 1D channels (rectangle and square), in which two kinds of water clusters arrays were observed. The structure of 2 exhibits a 3D network built by a 2D layer and a 1D Pb-O chain with hexagon channels, whereas 3 features a 3D open framework built by [Pb4(OH)4]4+ cluster units with 1D regular square channels. Thus, changing the reaction conditions causes the coordination modes of the ligand and the coordination geometry of metal ions, and consequently, several diversely structural frameworks with different channels to form. Lead ions are inclined to form distinct lead-hydroxo species in a large pH scale, which could act as a node. If other longer bridge ligands are in progress for these systems, much larger porous frameworks are expected. Significant phosphorescent emission is observed in three cases, as is expected from their structures.

Synthesis of [Pb(INO) 2 ] 2 ·7H 2 O (1). A mixture of Pb(NO3)2 (0.099 g, 0.3 mmol), isonicotinic acid N-oxide (0.0840 mg, 0.6 mmol), NaOH (0.024 g, 0.6 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was heated in a 23-mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner at 150 °C for 72 h and then was cooled to room temperature at 10 °C/h. Yellow needle crystals were obtained (0.133 g). The pH value of the solution was ca. 3.5. Yield:  81%. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C24H16N4O12Pb2·7H2O:  C, 26.35; H, 2.74; N, 5.12. Found:  C, 26.41; H, 2.85; N, 4.96. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3423s, 3109ms, 1585s, 1544m, 1482w,1378s, 1211s, 1174m, 1137m, 862m, 783w, 682w, 638m.

Synthesis of [Pb(INO) 2 ]· n H 2 O (2). The reaction was carried out in a molar ratio of 1:1.5 of Pb(NO3)2 (0.099 g, 0.3 mmol) to isonicotinic acid N-oxide (0.063 mg, 0.45 mmol) in 10 mL of water. To the solution were added NaOH (0.024 g, 0.6 mmol) and 5 mL of DMF, and white precipitate was observed. After the mixture was heated at 80 °C for 30 min with stirring, a majority of precipitate was resolved and then filtered. Yellow crystals were obtained from the filtrate by slow evaporation after standing 2 months at room temperature (yield:  0.033 g, 21% based on Pb). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C12H8N2O7.9Pb:  C, 28.03; H, 1.56; N, 5.45. Found:  C, 27.89; H, 1.67; N, 5.31. IR data (KBr, cm-1):  3418s, 3110ms, 1584s, 1542m, 1479w, 1379s, 1213s, 1176m, 1138m, 863m, 783w, 682w, 638m.

Synthesis of [Pb 4 (OH) 4 (INO) 4 ]· n H 2 O (3). A similar procedure with 1 was followed to prepare 3 except the mass of water (14 mL) was changed (yield:  0.08 g, 72% based on Pb). The pH value of the solution was adjusted to 5.5 through adding NaOH solid. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C24H16N4O23Pb4:  C, 18.51; H, 1.04; N, 3.60. Found:  C, 18.35; H, 1.13; N, 3.53. IR data (KBr, cm-1):  3395ms, 3108m, 1586s, 1543m, 1481vw, 1378s, 1212s, 1172m, 1136m, 861m, 781w, 682w, 637s.

cln_elements.content:
Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal stability of the porous MOF of 1−3 under flowing N2. The TGA curve of 1 shows an onset of water loss at a lower temperature of 45 °C and the 3D-MOF begins to decompose above 325 °C (Figure S2, Supporting Information). The first weight loss of 11.15% in the temperature range of 45−310 °C is in accordance with the loss of the lattice water molecules (calculated:  11.54%), while the second weight loss corresponds to the removal of all the organic components to yield PbO (found:  40.5%; calculated:  40.8%). The TGA curve of 2 shows one main weight loss of 5.42% between 35 and 80 °C before the compounds decompose at ca. 310 °C, which corresponds to the loss of the free water molecules (ca. 5.91%) from the channels (Figure S3, Supporting Information). The TGA curve of 3 shows that the first weight loss of 9.88% between 40 and 100 °C corresponds to the loss of the lattice water molecules (ca. 9.82%) in the channels. The anhydrous porous MOF remained stable up to ∼280 °C without any weight loss, showing that the 3D framework could retain structural integrity to ca. 280 °C (Figure S4, Supporting Information).

Moreover, the adsorption properties of compound 3 was investigated at room tempetature. The BET surface area of 3 is calculated to be only 2.51 m2/g, evidently being less than a typical value for microporous MOFs, so compound 3 shows a low adsorption ability to N2 (Figure S5, Supporting Information). These results reveal that only surface adsorption may occur in this case; that is, the nitrogen molecule could not diffuse into the inner channels of these solids freely despite the fact that they possess stable frameworks and large cavities.

Luminescent Properties. In this paper, the phosphorescent emission properties of compounds 1−3 were investigated in the solid state. Generally, the appearance of r.t. phosphorescence requires the presence of a heavy metal, which reduces the radiative lifetime of triplets by increased spin−orbit coupling. As shown in Figure , compound 1 exhibits red photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 628 nm upon excitation at 430 nm and the strongest absorption peak at 448 nm upon emission at 660 nm. Compound 3 exhibits an emission maximum at 632 nm upon excitation at 420 nm. In comparison to complex 1, a slight red shift of 4 nm has been observed in compound 3 because of the change of coordination geometry of the metal centers. The luminescent spectrum of compound 2 shows a great change with a blue shift of about 80 nm (λem = 547 nm) compared with those of compounds 1 and 3, which might derive from the slight difference of their structures. The luminescence of compounds 1−3 may be assigned to intraligand phosphorescent emission, while the presence of a heavy metal lead(II) ion facilitates intersystem crossing to successfully compete with radiationless deactivations of the triplet state.
